comments.commentBody: That's an incredibly stereotypical line of reasoning...plus the lack of freedoms and hyper conservativism in Islamic countries is certainly not something this country is striving for.  And the line about liberal taxpayers being outnumbered is hogwash - you are assuming Democrats are mostly on the dole and so are their voters with that ridiculous comment.  I would warrant there's plenty of each on both sides, but densely populated areas with varied information outlets and familiarity with the "other" (minorities religious, racial, or gender) vote overwhelmingly Democratic, (and Hillary got 3 million more VOTES I will remind you) while rural low information areas with a pretty homogenous population (white/Christian) with little familiarity of the "other" they've been taught to fear vote GOP. I assure you I'm a taxpayer at nearly 40% of my income and I don't like where Trump plans to spend MY hard earned dollars at all.
Trump was said to have assaulted almost everyone and everything during the election year and he still became president. It is not him that is standing in contempt here.
And it begs the question: What the heck was the Russian Ambassador doing at the Republican Convention?

Giving is always a far more acceptable way of helping the poor and the needy.

It's ironic that the esteemed Editorial Board is now recognizing the validity of giving over the wealth transfer schemes that they have been espousing and supporting now for decades.

Is the Editorial Board changing its tune?

I doubt that seriously. I also doubt that any of Board members give that generously to charities that actually help the disadvantaged, just as I doubt that any of the members voluntarily give more money to their local and state and our national governments when they file their taxes. I am sure that most of them mine the tax laws for every deduction that hey can possibly squeeze past an auditor.

When the Editorial Board steps up and leads by example, then I might be willing to grant their musings a touch of credibility.

The Editorial Board is composed of working stiffs. Minus their "musings" they don't get paid.
Dogs and cats will suffer... hookers and bookmakers as well.

Compassion is neither logically unsound nor immoral.

Giving is about helping people survive until such time as we elect people who will create the society without starvation and homelessness. Electing those people takes no money at all, only imagination and the will to do so.

The fact that the giver feels good about giving is only an added bonus.
This pope is not the shoe and chauffeur guy the last one was.

What a wonderful article, full of the wisdom of Pope Francis.  I am a Catholic and every time I hear or read about his inclusive views, I am thankful we have someone in a very high place looking out for humanity.  The world would be a much better place if we practice what he preaches and does.

You are arguing against a half-century policy that says that the only important thing is to take from those that earn and give it to those that don't.

The liberal...er...progressive...er...whatever it is that they are calling themselves these days to evade having to accept responsibility for the mess that adherence to their ideology has created for our nation...will never accept that as a realistic policy since it would involve the excision of the concept of "entitlement" from their thinking.

There are two important parts to the Pope's message. The money is secondary to our attitude towards those who are struggling on our streets and in our neighborhoods. When we make eye contact and say hello to someone we see regularly on the street, we recognize someone as a member of our community and a friend, someone we value. Imagine valuing the people who ask you for money, not their troubles or living situation. They are distant cousins to you, but family nonetheless. When we shake hands and look people in the eye, we are equals in that moment, we show respect and valuing. We feel the tenderness that keeps us whole.

Another idea is to give out "leftover bags" after a restaurant meal. It's criminal how much food is thrown out and yet how many people are hungry on the streets.  And, yes, give alms too, remembering to look the person in the eyes and recognize their humanness.
Having lived outside for three years during my deconstruction phase of human development, I completely agree that eye contact and a smile are more valuable than any coin.
Your comment would get more recommends if it had started after the comma.

Jesus states in Matt 25 that what you do for the poor is how he will recognize you "born again" status.  He told his disciples, who obviously accepted Jesus, that if you do not feed, clothe and provide shelter to all of the needy you are ware of then you witheld that aid from Jesus.  Pope Francis is scriptually on point.  Regardless of all of the other rules and traditions of the different branches of Christianity this appears to be Jesus giving a very clear command.  Your afterlife will be determined by how you treat the poor. Jesus never took a stand on birth control or abortion.  He observed the Sabbath on Saturday even with his time in the tomb after crucifixition (buried before sunset on Friday then rises on Sunday after Sabbath).   He defended a woman that under the old law could be stoned for adultery. Feeding and protecting the poor was his only clear line of behavior that affects salvation.  You can't be a follower of Christ without taking care of the poor.  That goes for the bishops and Cardinals that live princely lives and skimp on helping the poor.
Perplexing comment, Lisa. The reviewer actually saw the movie, but you're telling us to judge it based on a single reductive datum.

There is one person who knows, without any doubt, the nature of contacts between Trump associates and Russian operatives during and after the presidential campaign. While American journalists struggle to sort out the web of lies and distortions meant to keep these contacts secret, be assured that the person directing the scheme to attack our electoral process, without who's approval none of this could have taken place, is Putin himself.

What could take months or years for a special commission or special prosecutor to unravel, Putin could lay bare with news leaks. This could undo Trump and whatever agenda he might think of going forward. Looked at this way, Trump could be deeply in the pocket of the Russian despot. That Trump and his circle have put themselves in this position is disgraceful and a clear example of why our leaders shouldn't play footsie with dictators. He is subject to blackmail. Thus, Putin's intention to destabilize our electoral process and weaken Western democracies appears to have succeeded beyond what he could have realistically hoped.

Special commission/prosecutor are fine, but they could take time to work while it appears that compromised people are in the White House. Right now. I'm no lawyer, but I believe, based on reported phone recordings of Flynn talking to the Russian ambassador, that FISA court has issued a warrant allowing investigators to use the full power of NSA, etc., linking with allied intelligence abroad, to investigate this fully.

Republicans lept at every chance to investigate every move Hillary made. They spent millions of dollars and years at it. Suddenly, they've lost their taste for investigations. Isn't that....interesting?

The distressing thing is that this intelligence has been leaked, primarily by former officials of the former administration.  Why would any American patriot want to let those people know what we are doing?
It may be the only way to get the attention of the WH.
According the article, the proverbial cat is out of the bag.....
Perfect.  I always wanted to die in a nuclear holocaust so Donald Trump could exploit my death and stroke his fragile ego.

I am not sure how you arrived at the misconception that missile interceptors can protect the homeland.  If at all, I am positively impressed reading that the failure rate is only 56% under ideal conditions.  For all practical purposes we should assume that it doesn't work at all.
North Korea, the outcome of a country that wants to be cut off from the wider world and focus its resources on building a stronger military. Someone should tell the republicans in congress.

Let's pray that the adage "the enemy of my enemy is my friend" holds true in this case, since Kim Jong-un seems capable of carrying out actions of a true paranoid.  That could lead every nation in range of his ICBMs to resist and prevail.  It will be tragic if the North Korean people have to suffer severely due to the monstrosity of their tyrant.  Then again, better them than us.

Both Rs and Ds play the blame game. It is ludicrous to point the finger at Ds and call them obstructionists unless one points the same finger at Rs and calls them obstructionist for their behavior during the Obama years. Let's all grow up a little and focus on real issues like the nuclear threat posed by North Korea.

Paul, that is precisely why DPRK wants nuclear threat. Leverage for trade; food. But it's doubling down on terror. This is one of the few scenarios where "regime change," is not simply a national security interest, but a pan global security interest because targeting notwithstanding it is the distance those rockets can travel with a warhead that makes it a force multiplier; global threat.  Kim Jong-un is proving to be more unstable and bellicose than most intelligence officials could have anticipated. He's running away with the dish and the spoon and it would be an of preservation to see to his elimination. Sorry to say, but proved.

Your typical nuclear holocaust involves one country launching its missiles at another from their own territory. However, if North Korea wants to be sneaky, they only need to launch 2-3 missiles from container ships off our coast, explode them at an altitude of several hundred miles, and let the EMP from those bursts destroy our electric grid, autos, trains, planes, computers, phones, radio, etc. by shorting out their electronics.

While the anonymity of the aggressor is not guaranteed and we might nuke North Korea on spec, the result would still be that with communications and most transit disabled, we would most likely have confusion, mass starvation and disease to deal with.

It doesn't take a nuclear holocaust to shut us down. Because of our acceptance of electronics that is susceptible to EMP, most of our civilization would grind to a halt in such an attack.

This is different from a full scale nuclear attack in that it requires far fewer warheads which can be launched anonymously at sea from third party container ships which is well within North Korea's capabilities today. While our military would survive this attack, it is not clear that we would still have the ability to do the forensics after to determine the perpetrator. Plus we would have mass chaos to deal with after.

It is truly refreshing to see real news and in depth analysis for a change. I'm so sick of Trump's tweets and Democrats flailing at windmills. It seems we have lost sight of the real issues confronting the world and the US in particular that we ignore the 99% of what goes on that's really important.

This is a terrific, thought producing, reasonably in depth article about something that is really important.

This is why Trump’s obsession to expand military hardware – and drain the federal budget, including diplomacy and foreign aid and climate action to do it is so terrifying. Not only are we now dealing with two inept lunatics with control of nuclear codes, but we have two leaders who delight in provocation and no restraint (or intelligence) to exacerbate. Trump, like Bush/Cheney, is spoiling to be a war-time president because that smashes any political opposition, cements his control, gives him virtual martial law power. He has already shown his interest by telling the CIA on day 1, that “we may have a second chance at getting at Iraq’s oil” because, you know, he learned  when he was a boy that “to the victor belongs the spoils.” And this week, he reiterated his complaint that the US doesn’t win wars anymore. But the likelihood is that barring Trump instigating a new hot war, the next war will be fought in cyberspace, and the battlefield will be the electric grid, the financial networks and the utility plant.
